page.title: 01Nick of The Balloch
page.content: The ick o' the Balloch is a narrow hill pass with a single track rod leading from Balloch (on R. Stinchar) to Newton Stewart via Bbargrennan. The adjacent bare steep grassy hills rise up to 565m. a.s.l. separating Carrick Forest from Glentrool Forest, both part of the extensive Galloway Forest Park. Middle aged coniferous forests, mostly of Sitka Spruce, cover much of the lower slopes. Solely to preserve the striking scenic views, craggy corn Roy and Balloch Burn glens have been left unplanted. Hill sheep and black Galloway beef cattle graze the non afforested steep slopes and the high peaty plateux. There are no human dwellings in the Block. Brandy Well and Witches Bridgg are traditional local names associated with the Nick, one of the few passes through the hills from Ayreshire to Galloway
